class.name: Vector3i
class.description: A 3-element structure that can be used to represent 3D grid coordinates or any other triplet of integers. It uses integer coordinates and is therefore preferable to [Vector3] when exact precision is required. Note that the values are limited to 32 bits, and unlike [Vector3] this cannot be configured with an engine build option. Use [int] or [PackedInt64Array] if 64-bit values are needed. [b]Note:[/b] In a boolean context, a Vector3i will evaluate to [code]false[/code] if it's equal to [code]Vector3i(0, 0, 0)[/code]. Otherwise, a Vector3i will always evaluate to [code]true[/code].

constructor.name: Vector3i
constructor.description: Constructs a default-initialized [Vector3i] with all components set to [code]0[/code].

constructor.name: Vector3i
constructor.description: Constructs a [Vector3i] as a copy of the given [Vector3i].

constructor.name: Vector3i
constructor.description: Constructs a new [Vector3i] from the given [Vector3] by truncating components' fractional parts (rounding towards zero). For a different behavior consider passing the result of [method Vector3.ceil], [method Vector3.floor] or [method Vector3.round] to this constructor instead.

constructor.name: Vector3i
constructor.description: Returns a [Vector3i] with the given components.

method.name: abs
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components in absolute values (i.e. positive).

method.name: clamp
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components clamped between the components of [param min] and [param max], by running [method @GlobalScope.clamp] on each component.

method.name: clampi
method.description: Returns a new vector with all components clamped between [param min] and [param max], by running [method @GlobalScope.clamp] on each component.

method.name: distance_squared_to
method.description: Returns the squared distance between this vector and [param to]. This method runs faster than [method distance_to], so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

method.name: distance_to
method.description: Returns the distance between this vector and [param to].

method.name: length
method.description: Returns the length (magnitude) of this vector.

method.name: length_squared
method.description: Returns the squared length (squared magnitude) of this vector. This method runs faster than [method length], so prefer it if you need to compare vectors or need the squared distance for some formula.

method.name: max
method.description: Returns the component-wise maximum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector3i(maxi(x, with.x), maxi(y, with.y), maxi(z, with.z))[/code].

method.name: max_axis_index
method.description: Returns the axis of the vector's highest value. See [code]AXIS_*[/code] constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [constant AXIS_X].

method.name: maxi
method.description: Returns the component-wise maximum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector3i(maxi(x, with), maxi(y, with), maxi(z, with))[/code].

method.name: min
method.description: Returns the component-wise minimum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector3i(mini(x, with.x), mini(y, with.y), mini(z, with.z))[/code].

method.name: min_axis_index
method.description: Returns the axis of the vector's lowest value. See [code]AXIS_*[/code] constants. If all components are equal, this method returns [constant AXIS_Z].

method.name: mini
method.description: Returns the component-wise minimum of this and [param with], equivalent to [code]Vector3i(mini(x, with), mini(y, with), mini(z, with))[/code].

method.name: sign
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component set to [code]1[/code] if it's positive, [code]-1[/code] if it's negative, and [code]0[/code] if it's zero. The result is identical to calling [method @GlobalScope.sign] on each component.

method.name: snapped
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of the corresponding component in [param step].

method.name: snappedi
method.description: Returns a new vector with each component snapped to the closest multiple of [param step].

members.member: The vector's X component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][0][/code].
The vector's Y component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][1][/code].
The vector's Z component. Also accessible by using the index position [code][2][/code].

constants.constant: Enumerated value for the X axis. Returned by [method max_axis_index] and [method min_axis_index].
Enumerated value for the Y axis. Returned by [method max_axis_index] and [method min_axis_index].
Enumerated value for the Z axis. Returned by [method max_axis_index] and [method min_axis_index].
Zero vector, a vector with all components set to [code]0[/code].
One vector, a vector with all components set to [code]1[/code].
Min vector, a vector with all components equal to [code]INT32_MIN[/code]. Can be used as a negative integer equivalent of [constant Vector3.INF].
Max vector, a vector with all components equal to [code]INT32_MAX[/code]. Can be used as an integer equivalent of [constant Vector3.INF].
Left unit vector. Represents the local direction of left, and the global direction of west.
Right unit vector. Represents the local direction of right, and the global direction of east.
Forward unit vector. Represents the local direction of forward, and the global direction of north.
Back unit vector. Represents the local direction of back, and the global direction of south.

operator.name: operator !=
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are not equal.

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector3i] with the components of the given [Vector3i]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, -20, 30) % Vector3i(7, 8, 9)) # Prints "(3, -4, 3)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator %
operator.description: Gets the remainder of each component of the [Vector3i] with the given [int]. This operation uses truncated division, which is often not desired as it does not work well with negative numbers. Consider using [method @GlobalScope.posmod] instead if you want to handle negative numbers. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, -20, 30) % 7) # Prints "(3, -6, 2)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector3i] by the components of the given [Vector3i]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 20, 30) * Vector3i(3, 4, 5)) # Prints "(30, 80, 150)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector3i] by the given [float]. Returns a [Vector3]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 15, 20) * 0.9) # Prints "(9, 13.5, 18)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator *
operator.description: Multiplies each component of the [Vector3i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator +
operator.description: Adds each component of the [Vector3i] by the components of the given [Vector3i]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 20, 30) + Vector3i(3, 4, 5)) # Prints "(13, 24, 35)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator -
operator.description: Subtracts each component of the [Vector3i] by the components of the given [Vector3i]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 20, 30) - Vector3i(3, 4, 5)) # Prints "(7, 16, 25)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector3i] by the components of the given [Vector3i]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 20, 30) / Vector3i(2, 5, 3)) # Prints "(5, 4, 10)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector3i] by the given [float]. Returns a [Vector3]. [codeblock] print(Vector3i(10, 20, 30) / 2.9) # Prints "(5, 10, 15)" [/codeblock]

operator.name: operator /
operator.description: Divides each component of the [Vector3i] by the given [int].

operator.name: operator <
operator.description: Compares two [Vector3i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, and then with the Z values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator <=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector3i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is less than or equal to the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, and then with the Z values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator ==
operator.description: Returns [code]true[/code] if the vectors are equal.

operator.name: operator >
operator.description: Compares two [Vector3i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, and then with the Z values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator >=
operator.description: Compares two [Vector3i] vectors by first checking if the X value of the left vector is greater than or equal to the X value of the [param right] vector. If the X values are exactly equal, then it repeats this check with the Y values of the two vectors, and then with the Z values. This operator is useful for sorting vectors.

operator.name: operator []
operator.description: Access vector components using their [param index]. [code]v[0][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.x[/code], [code]v[1][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.y[/code], and [code]v[2][/code] is equivalent to [code]v.z[/code].

operator.name: operator unary+
operator.description: Returns the same value as if the [code]+[/code] was not there. Unary [code]+[/code] does nothing, but sometimes it can make your code more readable.

operator.name: operator unary-
operator.description: Returns the negative value of the [Vector3i]. This is the same as writing [code]Vector3i(-v.x, -v.y, -v.z)[/code]. This operation flips the direction of the vector while keeping the same magnitude.
